value.0: This secret, coveted art of the elves that is only possible to learn by those of elven blood is still a thriving practice in the region around the Wealdath, even if the population of elves is now only in the mere hundreds. This means that Arcane Archers stand out amongst their peers and will find recognition from mastering their art.
Arcane Archers in Tethyr: The Elven Arts

Assassins have a rich and colorful history in Tethyr. Several high profile assassinations have led to a superstition about the number five, even. These professional killers will easily find work in the south, seeing as conflicts inevitably draw upon those with their particular skills at hand.
Assassins in Tethyr: The Hidden Blades

The Council of Noromath is well known for their administration of Brost County and better known for their specific orders which demand the execution of any known bandits or criminals in the area. Outlaws receive little to no quarter in the Queen's lands, so even associating with their ilk can be a death sentence.
Bandits and Deserters

Though tribes of barbarians are rare, few and very far between in Tethyr and the surrounding lands, southern Faerun has a strong history of barbaric tribes. It was only a few thousand years before that roaming bands of humans, patrolling the edge of the massive Wealdath forest began to band together to form their own kingdom. Tethyr has not lost touch with its past culture - and many druidic practices that might be considered uncivilized elsewhere still take place on the northern plains and eastern reaches.
Barbarians in Tethyr

Bards are common throughout Faerun, and Tethyr is no exception. Wherever conflict seems to be, bards are not far behind, writing and singing songs of heroic acts on the battlefield. Just as joy can cause fantastic stories and songs, sorrow can twist into many dark tales around the campfire. Many bards flocked to Tethyr during the Interregnum, and many more still come to Tethyr now that tensions burn anew on the Amnian border. With no end in sight to the conflicts taking place, it can be assumed that Tethyr will continue to have a rich bardic culture and history for the decades to come.
Bards in Tethyr

You have been endowed with immense authority when it comes to seeking out and destroying heresy in all forms. Whichever church you serve, you have sworn your life to even higher ideals than most clerics. You will investigate, trial, punish and purge those who infect the parish and strive always to carry out your duties, no matter how unsavory they become.
Blackcoats in Tethyr: Inquisitions

Blackguards are much lesser known in Tethyr. When knights are able to contact wicked powers with the intensity of their evil desires, they mostly avoid the spotlight. The powers acquired by these men and women are anathema to most Tethyrian folk.
Blackguards in Tethyr: The Hidden Class

You have trained in the ancient Elven arts of warfare and magic, eventually learning to blend these arts into a deadly melee form. Learning the Bladesong is an extremely demanding pursuit, requiring very discrete tactics and precise movements in battle. This path will lead you to greater honors within Elven society, where master Bladesingers display their achievement by creating their own personalized elven chain mail armor and weaponry.
Bladesingers in Tethyr: Defenders of the Wealdath

The ancient groves around the village of Brost seem to be routinely visited by those who wish them ill- breaking the traditions held here for thousands of years. The results are visible to anyone. Creatures of undeath seem to plague the area, ruining nearby resources and fouling the land itself. It seems that these old holy sites are under attack and yet the harm this brings is a threat to everyone.
Blighters and the Groves

Blighters bring desolation wherever they tread. They are always from the ranks of ex-druids who have found a new power in corrupting or destroying nature instead of revering it. Surrounded by the flames of bitterness and hatred, they consume all life around them... It is no surprise that they must practice their arts in secret due to their ways being regarded as anathema by all peoples - civilized and savage alike.
Blighters in Tethyr: Burning the Wealdath

Queen Zaranda Star has ordered the expulsion of Tethyr's monstrous races. Although this order is considered to have been carried out to the letter, it remains the precedent by which monsters found in Tethyr are exterminated or driven out at any cost. Copies of the specific orders are able to be found all around, and anyone can claim aenar for doing the deed.
Bounties for Monstrous Creatures

Cavaliers are quite common in Tethyr, a land where the ability to ride a steed skillfully in combat can mean life or death. The cavalier blends an assortment of skills quintessential to most knights or soldiers.
Cavaliers in Tethyr: Seeking to Earn the Queen's Favor

Divine Champions are fairly common in Tethyr, where crusaders often seek to bring themselves closer to their deities through opportunities made available by the war. These warriors come from many different knightly orders and are as likely to be in harmony with each other as they are to be in conflict.
Divine Champions in Tethyr

The implications of Dragon Magic and specifically the process of a pact are things best left to sages... but they are happening when the wyrms of the Wealdath are as ancient and active as they are. Having a pact with a dragon means I am linked with its magic... And this power could lead to almost anything.
Dragon Disciples in Tethyr: The Dragon Pact

Druids are especially numerous and common within Tethyr. With the massive Wealdath constantly being consumed by drought and human expansion, vigilant champions of the forest are always needed both within and around the forest to ensure that loggers do not take too much and the balance is maintained. Of course, with the Wealdath, the druids are just as often seen battling the forest itself - which is known for swallowing entire battalions of men whole, never to be seen or heard from again.
Druids of the Wealdath: The Hidden Circles

The crumbling kingdom of Old Shanatar underfoot serves as a reminder to those dwarves who set out to make a name for themselves in Tethyr. Although some murmur critical things about the so-called dwarven defenders, they never do so loudly.
Dwarven Defenders in Tethyr: The Legacy of Shanatar

A life on the road with fellow adventurers has made a dabbler into something more dangerous, the flash of spells and steel producing an uncanny display of prowess. When the best tool at hand is a sword, it can always be improved upon by the right spells.
Eldritch Knights in Tethyr

The Tejarn Hills seem to hold a dark history. There was evidently a blackguard by the name of Fetton that started some of the troubles. Now, a shadow remains over the area, and when fiends are sighted it is surely due to meddlers following in Fetton's legacy.
Fetton's Folly

The past decade has been one filled with strife and conflict for Tethyr. Many men and peasants who thought they would never take up arms were forced or inspired to during the Interregnum. Many men and peasants thought they were done holding arms when Zaranda Star was crowned queen...Those same many men are now faced with the conflict with Amn, and while many are certainly uneasy at the thought, there others still that can't wait for a chance to fight a new enemy.
Fighters in Tethyr

Following the years of the Interregnum and then the rise of Queen Zaranda Star Rhindaun and King Haedrak III, the commoners of Tethyr are once again hopeful about the organization known as the Harpers. Although the past lingers in their minds, a future with the Harpers being more welcome seems possible.
Harpers in Tethyr: Rebuilding Trust
The Lieutenant mentioned a gravekeeper's body on the Tejard Trail.  Perhaps I should investigate?

The Grave Keeper had a note on his body. Apparently he was trying to collect the bounties on the zombies to make some extra coin. Poor sod. He was going to visit a man named Sir Rembert Keiner in the Brost Cemetary to see about more work.
After speaking with Sir Rembert, I was made aware of the Duskwood to the west, apparently utterly infested with undead. He asked me to visit the Kelemvorite Shrine to ensure it was maintained.
The Shrine of Kelemvor had seen better days, but I was able to make sure an offering for Kelemvor was placed. It seemed as though there would be no shortage of undead foes to fell in this place.
Investigate the Undead

Welcome to Lands of Intrigue!

Your story takes place primarily in Tethyr, though portions of the other Lands of Intrigue will play a part.  Whether you were born here or come from abroad you will find that your choices and your background play a significant role once you arrive in Brost County, though where you go from there is entirely up to you.  Whatever the case, the Lands of Intrigue will live up to their name.

Tethyr itself is in a state of high tension, poised on the brink of potential political turmoil.  Queen Anais Rhindaun lacks an heir to her throne, and there are those in the shadows that seek to take advantage of this, once more plotting stage a coup and position her niece as Queen instead.  In the Duchy of Noromath, where your journey begins, things are no less dire.  Duke Allain "Foxfire" Kevanarial, aloof and absent from much of his political duties over the years, has been killed.  By who or what is unknown, but what is known is that despite the wayward Elven Lord's historic absence from politics, his murder has still left a power vaccuum that is yet to be filled.

To compound it all, conflict with Amn seems all but certain due to recent troubles along the trade way with Amnian merchant caravans being attacked by unknown assailants.

Whoever you once were or whatever you strive to be, one thing is for sure - the Lands of Intrigue are ripe with equal measure of danger and adventure.

For information about the setting, server rules, and to meet fellow players, please join our Discord: https://discord.gg/ZRgsBj48uC
Lands of Intrigue

If you ask a Calishite Historian, all of the lands of Tethyr were once part of the Shoon Imperium, even including the northernmost duchies of Amn. The signs of this Calishite immigration are everywhere in Brost. Even the castles and the stonework is of Calishite make. It seems that even if Tethyrians have reclaimed these lands, certain places will not cede themselves to the present... The Sentinel Tower, the Aljana Warrens, and the sewers below Westhaven all resist being buried.
Legacy of Shoon

Devotion of the mind, body and soul to a cause is nothing new in Tethyr. Eastern philosophies of Chi and a spiritualistic view of the world have been present in Western Faerun for hundreds of years. Temples devoted to the gods have taken their fair share of these ideas and warped them towards their own ideals over time. Tethyr itself boasts many temples, hidden in far distant reaches, where evil worshipers take advantage of these little understood forces while working to make themselves whole. Mind, body, and soul.
Monks in Tethyr: Discipline in the Far South

You awaken to a different perception of the world. Sounds are crisp and loud in your ears, while colors and tastes are more vivid and defined than ever before. Yet, something in the back of your mind seems dull and numb and controlled by another will than your own. Lights are brighter than they used to be. You feel yourself become agitated more easily. Something is surely amiss... But you also feel much stronger and faster than before.

You were wounded mortally and something terrible happened. It was swift, but the change seems to slowly take hold. You fear the light of the sun and the power of true priests. Your place is in the safety of the darkness and behind the veil of secrecy, even as you come to realize that you are now a vampire and you must feed on the blood of the living to survive. Rage and anger fill your heart. It will take all of your will to resist your new nature.

Sages have argued long over the fate of slain vampires and the true nature of the creatures known as Crimson Deaths, but you have experienced this horrible transformation first-hand. With your body destroyed, your vampiric soul now drifts in the most awful, agonizing state of being imaginable.
One with the Dead...

The orc tribes of the Small Teeth Mountain range are the worst of their sort, according to what I keep hearing. They have infested an old keep in the contested lands between Tethyr and Amn. Some rangers in the area are saying that as many as four tribes are cooperating, which is uncommon. Whatever their reason for working together, the reports say that these orcs seem to be able to effectively use the terrain and the resources around them.
Orc Tribes of the Small Teeth

The past decade has seen a rise in the knightly orders of Torm, Tyr and Ilmater as the Triad's influence has remained a constant - especially in the eastern reaches of Tethyr. With Zaranda Star's rise to power, the paladin orders have a wider reaching influence than ever before and stand to help a great many of the kingdom's citizens with their everyday troubles and trials. But, darkness still lurks in Tethyr, and politics often play a larger role than the "greater good" of humanity. When the peasantry need help, paladins and knights are usually the first to answer...Though even paladins need to watch their backs while in the fringe-lands of Tethyr.
Paladins in Tethyr: The Never Ending Crusade

Pale Masters in Tethyr represent the darkest students of necromancy. Known for seeking hidden knowledge and spending long hours in questionable places to find it, Pale Masters are anathema to all people and cultures. They are hunted with great zeal by many servants of the light; and with good reason.
Pale Masters in Tethyr: Seeking the Legacy of Shoon

Nearly every god is paid lip-service in Tethyr, and many places where one might expect a temple devoted to a single deity, there is typically a shrine dedicated to all of the gods. That isn't to say there is a shortage of clerics - faithful in service to the gods are highly common in Tethyr, especially after the past and current conflicts. Even lesser-known gods of nature are highly regarded, especially in the lands around the Wealdath, where Silvanus and Eldath are revered as greater than or equal to the better-known gods of Faerun.
Priests in Tethyr

The Wealdath has long been home to many elves, but it has also been home to humans as well. Only the roughest of men, who have absolutely devoted themselves to nature and all it has to give, can survive in a forest that repels and reviles their very existence. These hardened men are common, especially in northern Tethyr, and do not only respect and aid the druidic circles - but maintain their own societies to meet their own means.
Rangers in Tethyr: The Wealdath is Home

Upon speaking with a Knight of Agis at the Tejarn Gate, I was told I would need to travel to the Village of Brost and see the County Record Keeper to ensure my name was recorded for tax purposes. There would be an office inside the large government building, the Ranger's Rest.
After speaking with Lisa Pendleton at the Record Keeper's Office, I am now officially a denizen of Brost County.
Register with the County

Outlaws, charlatans, thieves and more were common in Tethyr long before the Interregnum. With the Civil War at its end, their power and influence has only grown. While some have settled into a more modest means of living, taking to the city where politics or riches await, others still plague the country side as bandits and robbers on horseback. A constant thorn in the side of knights and peasants alike.
Rogue's in Tethyr: A Land of Strife and Opportunity

The shadows are long and dark in the unstable northern highlands. The castles are understaffed and the cold walls and tapestries are rich with the power of the Shadow Weave. The silence is sometimes so long and perfect that I can see why this is the ideal place to practice my darkest arts.
Shadow Adepts in Tethyr: Living the Veil

Shadow Dancers are seen in the south in dancing troupes, circuses, or a Pasha's den entertaining guests with sensual displays. They can also come from the mercenary background or even be found worshiping the goddess Shar; always finding new insights as they study the darkness.
Shadow Dancers in Tethyr: In the Shadow of Intrigue

For a long time, Tethyr was buried in the shadow of Calimshan and it's djinn magics. The affair with Calimshan and it's citizens has left a stain on Tethyr ever since, with sorcerers blood from the djinn mixing and mingling with the magic of the dragons. Though it is rare, these innatists are born on a regular basis at all rungs of society, where their power could be their undoing or the beginning of a fantastic tale.
Sorcerers in Tethyr: Journey of the Blood

All the caravans seem unwilling to go further west, so Brost really is the end of the line. The Ogre Mage Sothillis seems to have both the Tethyrian and Amnian militaries occupied with the siege in distant Murann. Although it is only a small part of the ogre army that we are seeing in Westhaven, their numbers seem impossible to exhaust.
Sothillis the Ogre Mage and his Army

Spellfire is the raw energy of The Weave. Most who bear this gift never have the time or opportunity to develop this skill. Those who do practice their spellfire are able to hone their talent into a tool with fantastic abilities that most dabblers can only dream of. Many people want to take or exploit the power of spellfire for themselves, so you have taken to the far south where the troubles of the place will serve as a place for you to blend in.
Spellfire Channelers in Tethyr: Hiding in the South

When you come in contact with the statue depicting one of the emperors of the Shoon Imperium, Amahl Shoon IV, a stroke of power enters your being and makes you whole again. You feel the contact with the statue may have taken something away from you, however.
Statues of Shoon IV

Queen Anais Rhindaun sits upon the throne of Tethyr and governs with a firm, just hand, but still, her rule is not secure.  Her early reign was plagued by both personal and political turmoil and the seeds of both doubt and conspiracy remain.  With no direct heir for the throne, many begin to wonder what will occur upon her death, and if she truly deserves to sit the throne at all...
Tethyr's Troubles

In my time in Brost, I have learned of a noble house that has since left the County. They seem to have left their mark by way of a great flood that killed at least several hundred more than a century ago. The tale I have heard spun is of love between a Druid of the Grove who's a name everyone refuses to give and the noble family's daughter. They were the owners of the Manor House located in the Duskwood - the center of an undead blight.
The Banned Druid
Day 1 - Something seems wrong, you can't quite put your finger on it. The world is dragging you down and you feel tired.
Day 2 - You look and feel like you have begun to waste away. Moving is a chore and you feel incredibly weak.
Day 3 - You feel very close to death. Whatever afflicts you is taking its toll on your body. You are wasting away at a fast pace and you doubt whether you may survive another night...
I am complete.
The Disease

The area around you seems like some kind of magical construction. You sense the faint whispers of what may be the fragments of spectres or waiting souls not unlike your own, accumulating their willpower in advance of returning to the world.
The Great Black

The country to the north of the Tethir Road, Amn, is known as "The Merchants' Domain." It is among the youngest nations of the southern Sword Coast. If the adage "Follow the money, and ye shall find answers to many mysteries" were true, every investigator and adventurer would end up in Amn, since money flows there as to no other county. Nearly every merchant does business with Amn or passes through it during the course of a year's business deals. Amn's location benefits its mercantile nature, as it is the springboard for Calishite and Tethyrian products heading north to the Heartlands. The country's rich natural resources and its peoples' knack for business soon led Amn to seize its premier status as one of the most important centers of trade in the Realms. Amn is as important as Sembia and Waterdeep even in their own respective geographic markets, and all three countries have long-established rivalries. Amn's future is uncertain at best, with bright and dark strains. 

Its merchants and priests have discovered a new country to the west, Maztica, which Amn is colonizing and expoilting-producing trouble at home and abroad. 

Amn's neighbor to the south, Tethyr, has finally stabilized into a rich, promising trading partner. However, some Amnian cities are on the verge of rebellion, aiming to join Tethyr.  With the uncertain state of Tethyr's Royal Line of succession such rumors could either be tantalizing or a death trap depending on the one involved.

Rumors of monstrous armies are often heard of late. As always, power groups inside Amn and elsewhere vie for supremacy, so much that outsiders view Amn as a stew pot of conspiracy and chaos. For the natives, however, it matters little who is in power so long as business continues to run uninterrupted.
The Lands of Intrigue: Amn

When many think of Calimshan, they think of sand and silks, jewels and genies, slaves and slain rivals, and heat. The Land of the Three Rivers (one of Calimshan's many long-unused titles) is all these things and more. It is a land steeped equally in culture and corruption, in history and greed. Calimshan embraces a world of contrasts, as its rich are affluent beyond measure just as its poor are destitute beyond belief. It is another world whose inhabitants embrace magic and education but jealously guard them from those they deem unworthy. While confusing to outsiders, Calimshan and its people accept these seemingly contradictory values as life, and it is the outsider's place to learn how to adapt to the Land of the Pashas rather than the alternative.
The Lands of Intrigue: Calimshan

The focus of our campaign, Tethyr, is one of the oldest settled lands on the face of Faerun, though few today remember it as such. When one speaks of Tethyr, anyone born in this century thinks only of a land rife with political intrigue, civil unrest, prejudice against demihumans, and assassination. What was one of the noblest of human countries reduced itself to a lawless land. The two decades of the Alemandrian Interregnum increased the ranks of robber barons, criminals, monsters, and religious zealots in the area, further destabilizing it. Though the ascent of Queen Monarch Zaranda Star years ago saw an end to much of this strife, the current days of Tethyr seem poised to topple once more into uncertainty.

The year is 1494.  26 years ago Anais Rhindaun ascended the throne of Tethyr and her early reign was plagued with internal strife and external tragedy.  Though she eventually secured her rule, the political state of Tethyr is poised on the edge of a Knife.  Lacking a direct heir and fostering the daughter of her traitorous sister, there are those both within and without the Royal Court that seek to take advantage of the tumultous climate and sieze power for themselves.
The Lands of Intrigue: Tethyr

From my travels around the county, I have often heard of Calishite merchants that ply their trade. One name has stood out amongst them, however. They call her the Daughter of the Lord of Shisha - apparently someone of note in Calimport. Arwa yr Hissa el Salih is a political machinator in the county, keeping a low profile while searching for an orb of some sort. The peasants speak of misfortunes that have followed those that have apparently found this mysterious orb - including the mysterious Sir Godric of Kelemvor.
The Orb of Calim

Tracking

Sentient undead in Tethyr are living under an immense shadow... It is a darkness that blots out all hope and light. Something that directs my every single movement like a master puppeteer, something that remains a step ahead as it seems to superintend my growth. I know not whether I will be harvested or exalted in the days to come, but those of my kind keep whispering that the Master is coming. He may already be here.
Undead in Tethyr: Legacy of the Shoon

There seem to be lots of caves and other various entry points to the deep underground; rumors speak of Old Shanatar, the lost Dwarven kingdom. Evidently, it rests right below our feet, along with all its riches. Recent worries about grey dwarves and even drow have locals on edge, with most saying that all the vast wealth of Shanatar surely isn't worth the swift death you'll catch down below.
Underdark Threats

Born of a supernatural bloodline, a warlock seeks to master the perilous magic that suffuses his soul. Unlike sorcerers or wizards, who approach arcane magic through the medium of spells, a warlock invokes powerful magic through nothing more than an effort of will. By harnessing his innate magical gift through fearsome determination and force of will, a warlock can perform feats of supernatural stealth, beguile the weak-minded, or scatter his foes with blasts of eldritch power.
Warlocks in Tethyr: The Hidden Class

Weapon Masters in Tethyr can expect plenty of opportunities to distinguish themselves with things such as knighthood or even land ownership in reward for their exceptional deeds. Since Weapon Masters can routinely perform the extraordinary, soldiers flock to them for training or even a glimpse of insight.
Weapon Masters in Tethyr: The Path to Fame

During the Interregnum, the Towers of Mystra fell into disarray and ruin from unknown causes. Mages were drafted tenfold into the Civil War to fight in battle for both sides and learning fell by the wayside. Now, with the war at it's end, wizards are beginning to regain their strength and form new enclaves from the ashes of the old...Or at least, they have done their best to conceal themselves before the wizards of Amn have stolen them away.
Wizards in Tethyr: The Return of High Arcana
